cpystal.core package

Submodules

cpystal.core.core module

cpystal: for dealing with crystals and experimental data of physical property.

cpystal is designed to handle experimental data on crystals. It places particular emphasis on calculating and storing data on the properties of actual synthesized samples, and on graphing these data. In this respect, it is distinct from pymatgen, a similar crystal and material analysis module. Of course, pymatgen is a very useful python module, so we use it as an adjunct in cpystal.

class cpystal.core.core.Crystal(name: str, date: str | None = None, auto_formula_weight: bool = True)[source]

Bases: object

A Crystal instance corresponds to a certain sample of a crystal.

Note

Any attribute of a Crystal instance can be freely assigned from the time it is created until the end of the program (i.e. mutable). However, once it is saved as a pickle file, it becomes impossible to change the attributes of the instance created by loading from the pickle file (i.e. immutable). This feature was implemented to prevent the unintentional destruction of the sample data which is saved in a pickle file.

name

The chemical formula of the crystal.

Type:

str

graphname

TeX-formed name.

Type:

str

date

The date the sample was synthesized. If there is a numbering system, it will be included here.

Type:

str | None

spacegroup_name

Space group name in International (Hermann-Mauguin) notation of the crytal.

Type:

str

NA

Avogadro constant 6.02214076 * 10**(23) [mol^-1].

Type:

float

muB

Bohr magneton 9.27401 * 10**(-21) [emu].

Type:

float

kB

Boltzmann constant 1.380649 * 10**(-23) [J/K].

Type:

float

a

Lattice constant [Å].

Type:

Type:

cal_effective_moment(Curie_constant: float) → float[source]

Calculating effective moment from the value of Curie constant.

Note

C = Nμ^2/3kB μ^2 = g^2 J(J+1) μB^2 where N is the number of magnetic ion per mol,

g is Lande factor, J is total angular momentum quantum number.

(emu*Oe = erg = 10^(-7) Joule)

Parameters:

Curie_constant (float) – Curie constant (unit: [emu.K/mol.Oe]).

Returns:

Effective moment μ/μB = g√J(J+1).

Return type:

(float)

cal_ingredients() → list[tuple[str, float]][source]

Calculating the weight of each element in the sample.

Returns:

list of tuple (element name, element weight ratio to the total).

Return type:

(list[tuple[str, float]])

cal_magnetization(m: float, w: float | None = None, SI: bool = False, per: str | None = None) → float[source]

Calculating magnetization from measured value of magnetic moment.

Parameters:

  • m (float) – Magnetic moment (unit: [emu]).

  • w (float | None) – The weight of the sample (unit: [g]).

  • SI (bool) – If True, magnetization is calculated in SI (MKSA) system.

  • per (str | None) – If per == “mol”, magnetization per mol is calculated. If per == “weight”, magnetization per weight is calculated.

Returns:

Magnetization (unit: [G], [G/mol], [G/g], [A/m], [A/m/mol] or [A/m/kg]).

Return type:

(float)

cal_mol() → float[source]

Calculating the amount of substance of the sample from the weight of the sample.

Returns:

The amount of substance of the sample (unit: [mol]).

Return type:

(float)

cal_phonon_velocity(TD: float) → float[source]

Calculating phonon velocity from Debye temperature.

Note

k_B T_D = hbar omega_D = hbar v k_D, where Debye wave number k_D satifies 4/3 pi k_D^3 = (2pi)^3 N / V, where N is the number of atom in the sample and V is the volume of the sample.

Parameters:

TD (float) – Debye temperature (unit: [K]).

Returns:

Phonon velocity (unit: [cm/s]).

Return type:

(float)

cal_weight() → float[source]

Calculating the weight of the sample from the amount of substance of the sample.

Returns:

The weight of the sample (unit: [g]).

Return type:

(float)

class cpystal.core.core.Energy(quantity: float, unit: str)[source]

Bases: object

from energy to other physical quantity or vice versa.

Note

All units stand for SI.

Parameters:

  • quantity (float) – Quantity part of a physical quantity.

  • unit (str) – Unit part of a physical quantity.

Example

1 meV -> 11.6 K 1 THz -> 4.14 meV

to(new_unit: str) → Energychild[source]

Translate the physical quantity as other units.

Parameters:

new_unit (str) – New unit.

Example

1 meV -> 11.6 K 1 THz -> 4.14 meV

class cpystal.core.core.MPMS(filename: str, material: Crystal)[source]

Bases: object

This is a class for acquiring experimental data of Magnetic Property Measurement System (MPMS) from ‘.dat’ files.

filename

Input file name (if necessary, add file path to the head). The suffix of filename may be “.dat”.

Type:

str

material

Crystal instance of the measurement object.

Type:

Crystal | None

N

Length of data.

Type:

int

Temp

Temperature (K) data.

Type:

list[float]

Field

Magnetic field (Oe) data.

Type:

list[float]

Time

Time stamp (sec) data.

Type:

list[float]

LongMoment

Longitudinal moment (emu) data.

Type:

list[float]

Regfit

Regression fit of longitudinal moment data.

Type:

list[float]

Bpfu() → list[float][source]

Moment list in ‘μB/f.u.’.

Field_T() → list[float][source]

Field list in ‘Testa’.

Susceptibility(H: float, magnification: float = 1.0) → list[float][source]

χ=M/H list in ‘emu/mol.Oe’.

Parameters:

  • H (float) – Magnetic field (Oe).

  • magnification (float) – Amplification magnification. Defaults to 1.0.

cal_Curie_Weiss_temp(temp: list[float], moment: list[float], field: float) → tuple[float, float][source]

Calculating Curie-Weiss temperature and Curie constant.

Note

χ = M/H = C / (T-θc), where θc is Curie-Weiss temperature and C is Curie constant

Parameters:

  • temp (list[float]) – list of temperature (K). Elements must be above Curie (or Neel) temperature.

  • moment (list[float]) – list of magnetic moment (emu).

Returns:

Curie-Weiss temperature (K) and Curie constant (emu.K/mol.Oe).

Return type:

(tuple[float, float])

inv_Susceptibility(H: float, magnification: float = 1.0) → list[float][source]

1/χ=H/M list in ‘(emu/mol.Oe)^{-1}’.

Parameters:

  • H (float) – Magnetic field (Oe).

  • magnification (float) – Amplification magnification. Defaults to 1.0.

(optional

when used PPMS_Resistivity.set_S_l)

Type:

Type:

float

Type:

lyx

Type:

set_S_l(Sxx: float, lxx: float, Syx: float, lyx: float) → None[source]
symmetrize(delta_H: float, up_data: LLF, down_data: LLF) → tuple[LF, LF, LF, LF, LF][source]

Symmetrization and antisymmetrization are performed based on the data of the field-increasing and field-decreasing processes.

Parameters:

  • delta_H (float) – Difference of the magnetic field between each step.

  • up_data (list[list[float]]) – list of [field (float), Rxx (float), Rxx_sd (float), Ryx (float), Ryx_sd (float)] which represents field-increasing data.

  • down_data (list[list[float]]) – list of [field (float), Rxx (float), Rxx_sd (float), Ryx (float), Ryx_sd (float)] which represents field-decreasing data.

Returns:

The first element of return value is ‘effective_field’ that is the list of field value whose reverse field value exists in data. The second and third element of return value is the list of Rxx and Rxx_sd. The fourth and fifth element of return value is the list of Ryx and Ryx_sd.

Return type:

(tuple[list[float], list[float], list[float]], list[float], list[float])

class cpystal.core.core.SemimutableDict(*args: Any)[source]

Bases: Dict[Any, Any]

Semi-mutable dictionary inherited from dict

The only difference from dict is that using [] is not allowed, but using update_force method is allowed to replace the value.

update_force(key: Any, value: Any) → None[source]

Instance method for replacing the value.

Parameters:

  • key (Any) – Immutable object.

  • value (Any) – New value of key.

cpystal.core.core.ingredient_flake_dp(A: list[int], W: int) → None[source]

Choose optimal flakes whose total weight meets the target value.

Note

The result will be output to stdout.

Parameters:

  • A (list[int]) – list of weight of flakes, properly integerized.

  • W (int) – Target weight value.

merge(x: int, y: int) → bool[source]

Note

Returns:

Return type:

root(x: int) → int[source]

Return the number of the root of x.

Note

Time complexity is O(α(n)), where n is the size of the entire set and α(n) is the inverse Ackermann function. This function satisfies the relation:

A(α(n)-1, α(n)-1) < n <= A(α(n), α(n)).

Parameters:

x (int) – The number of the element.

Returns:

The number of the root of x.

Return type:

int

Time complexity is O(n), where n is the size of the entire set.

Parameters:

x (int) – The number of the element.

Returns:

The number of the size of the group to which x belongs.

Return type:

int
